Although my debates are based more on which guy was cooler looking rather than skillful I have several nominies.
 Jimi Hendrix -- I know that I am sounding cliche for saying this, but he was the master. He could make all sorts of beautiful sounds on a guitar.
 Jerry Garcia -- I grew up listening to the Grateful Dead since I was little and naturally love Jerry. He could play fast, skillfully, and I have never heard another guitar sound like his.
 Clapton -- He was a great songwriter but lacked some skills held by the greats.
 Jimmy Page -- Now this in my opinion is the best hard rock guitarist in the history of music. Every time I hear "Dazed and Confused" I breath slowly and wonder 'how does he do it?'

Hendrix and Santana are pretty good. Hendrix because of his wild antics on stage and Santana for writing good songs with actual words (instead of Jimi's random grunts) and for still having the amazing control of the guitar even at his age.

Hendrix because he had a real "relationship" with his guitar on stage.
 
 Santana because he has such a unique sound, more than others imo.

Neal Schon is a god.

 
 Amen brother! Most folks are only familiar with the commercial Journey, but the work he did during that time is nothing compared to early Journey and his solo stuff. No disrespect to Hendrix and Page, they are/were good, but I've always felt they are included for sentimental reasons. Schon has whipped off solos that leave them all in his dust

BB King
 Carlos Santana 
 PRINCE!
 and my friend Travis Lee Merchant :)

This topic (Best Guitarist) is misnamed. There are too many styles to say who is the best overall. I would put the rock guitarists at the bottom of the pile, since they depend on over-driven amplifiers to creat a great deal of their "sound". This does not mean I think they are not talented. Stevie Ray belongs at the top of their list.
 
 I would put Carlos Montoya at the top of the classical list.
 
 I would put Michael Hedges on a list by himself.
 
 ...and certainly Leo Kottke is great.
 
 There are many great guitarists, several of which have already been posted...but I believe the best is yet to come.

The Edge
 
 Carlos Santana
 
 Jeff Beck
 
 Tom Verlaine

Soulful: Stevie Ray Vaugn
 Audibly: Jeff Beck
 
 My Favorite and biasedly would say is best: John Petrucci
 
 There are lots of great guitarist. Pointless thread.

 He was a great song-writer in a great band. That does not mean he was a great guitar player.
 
 Look at U2. You may not like them, but there is no arguing how huge they are. Millions of fans worldwide for more than twenty years. Personally, I love them. But there is also no question that Adam Clayton is mediocre bass player at best. 
 
 Cobian was a great and you can like him all you like - but he will never be remembered for his guitar work. It's doubtful many from the grunge scene will be. They kind of moved away from clever guitar riffs and solos. It wasn't part of the sound. Which is fine. They majorly impacted rock and gave it's multi-dimensionalism another face. But they weren't 'guitar' bands. 
 
 I was watching Prince play an acoustic last night on TV - never seen that before. He is amazing. Did I mention Joe Walsh before? Man - I took my mom to the Eagles and alomost fell asleep from all the strumming chords - and then Joe took center stage and blew my mind. Clapton is amazing but dull live. BB King has so much feeling. Santana plays sexy. Rockabilly chicken picking is always fun. OH - and in the country world - Junior Brown - he is oh so many shades of WOW. mmmmm - - Leslie likes guitar.....

 Exactly as Jito said, Nirvana was a great group, and I own some CD's too, but I just cannot see great guitar playing in it. Great performer, great lyricist, great singer (when he wanted to be), but certainly not a great guitar player. Cobain brought a new style of music to the foreground and will always be remembered for that, but certainly not his guitar work.

 I have not heard of them. What is their sound like?
 
 When it comes to lyrics I lean towards the well-known giants - Bono, Lennon, Dylan, Springsteen. Other good ones I like are Live, NIN, Mary Chapin Carpenter, Cake.
 
 And there is always the very clever random lyric from the random band/artist who is generally not a great lyricist - -
 
 "I'm a concientious objector to the war that's in my mind." - Green Day
 "I was kissing Valentino by a Crystal Blue Italion Stream" - Prince
 
 I think my all time favorite lyric is from One by U2
 
 "Did you come here for forgiveness?
 Did you come to wake the dead?
 Have you come here to play Jesus, 
 to the lepers in your head?"
 
 I also love this one by the Boss - 
 
 "I had a job
 I had a girl
 I had something going, mister, in this world
 
 I got laid off
 at the lumber yard
 Our love went bad, times got hard
 
 Now I work down at the carwash, where all it ever does is rain...

 I'm no expert on guitarists but have always been impressed with Stevie Ray Vaughan and Jimmy Page. As for lyricists, I love U2 as and Springsteen as musicians but am more impressed with Bob Dylan or Simon and Garfunkel, and possibly Lennon. By the way, I think most artists' lyrics are terrible. Many of these people are great at music making, but they clearly are not poets. One artist whose lyrics and delivery of lyrics that really irritates me is Alanis Morrisette.

 We have Les Paul to thank for inventing the electric guitar. He wired some magnetic pickups to a couple of pieces of solid hardbody and played a gig in an obscure New York City nightclub where he said the audience became very enthusiastic about the sound. His playing was as electric as his instrument, and completely innovative. Suddenly the guitar was no longer an unassuming instrument chording in the background of big bands, but took its rightful place up front. 
 
 It was up to Chet Atkins to master it though.
